title: Thursday, 28th June, 2018
bodyHTML:

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 770.98, up 15.78 (+2.09%), High: 779.80, Low: 742.40, Volume: 1.80m
BE11:14am

Okay, so here's how the rules work.

Flaneur @BE - FTAVs Kalingrad article (just published) isnt much above that Musk article.
BE11:15am

If you have something to say about your likely current-year outcome you need to say it via a timely RNS or the FCA will hunt you down like dogs.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

However.

BE11:15am

If you have something to say about next year, do what you want.

Blank canvas good morning all
BE11:16am

Margin warning for 2019 to 2021? Cool. Just chuck it out to the private audience at a CMD. That's fine. That's not selective disclosure, apparently.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

That's more or less what happened yesterday, and led Just Eat to fall out of bed by about 10%.

BE11:17am

Today, we get a lot of sellside saying "okay, so profit's a lot lower but look, people will still need takeaways in the future so ......."

BE11:17am

Liberum, for instance.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

The market reacted negatively to Just Eat’s guidance comments at its Capital Markets Day with management stating that adjusted EBITDA margins in its core Marketplace business would remain flat and revenue growth would track more closely order growth, as opposed to exceeding it, both of which raised fears over significant medium to long-term downgrades. However, we came away feeling more confident on Just Eat’s structural position, and, while we will review numbers, we suspect some of these concerns are overdone with a strong 2018 potentially leading to a higher base and a possibly very significant “halo” effect from the launch of Delivery services.

BE11:18am

Halo eff-what?

BE11:18am

Management commented that, far from cannibalising its existing business, offering Delivery actually seems to increase orders by around two per Delivery due to the greater choice of products driving customers to order more. Their guidance does not reflect this halo effect. However, if it does continue, that means that order growth is likely to be stronger than expected, especially as management suggested that 1/3 of the business could be Delivery in the future (suggesting scale) and that the economics from the halo effect were very attractive.

rw42 Uh, all the product choice in the world won't make me eat more than my stomach can hold (and i push the limits already)!
Swedish Chef @flan at least the FT calls Kalingrad an exclave. BBC uses enclave at times.
11:19 am
BE11:20am

So, buy up to 850p. That's on 16.7p EPS for the current year so, what, 45-ish?.

BE11:20am

We would place Just Eat in the potential same category as stocks such as Rightmove (HOLD, TP 5000p) and Scout 24 (BUY, TP €46) i.e. leading online classified portals that have extremely attractive characteristics such as benefiting from strong network effects, high operational leverage and very attractive cashflows. However, unlike the two companies mentioned above, Just Eat’s market leading position is not yet enshrined as the structural transition from old to new has a while to go (42% of orders in the UK are still made over the telephone) and there are aggressive entrants such as Uber Eats. It thus makes perfect sense to spend now to ensure that Just Eat retains and strengthens its position.

BE11:20am

.... sure sure. Be nice if forecasts went up sometime soon to grow into that valuation, though. Seems a while since they went up.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Barclays also.

Tom Dalgleish Maybe the food deliverers can do booze too
BE11:22am

To capitalise on this opportunity and to fend off competition it is clear that JE is investing heavily into brand, local merchant support, IT and logistics. The lack of granularity around revenue impact and the comment on margin resulted in the market reducing margin without lifting revenue. We further upgrade our revenues, but reign in EBITDA; however, we remain above 2019 consensus (BBg) on pre-CMD level, as we believe the consensus EpS d⁄g is unwarranted.

BE11:23am

And Merrill.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

We cut 13% from 2019e EBITDA. But valuation prices this in; JE trades at a 32% discount to loss-making TKWY on EV/GMV (2019). We believe few people would dispute that JE's decision to prioritise growth is right, so we expect stock to bounce back. Buy.

BE11:24am

Etc.

Puntino But Just Eat is a bargain when compared to Delivery Hero on 70x 2020e, so buy.
Swedish Chef @tom is there a business to be built on rapid home delivery of booze. Ready chilled Chablis at 8pm. A litre of cheap vodka at midnight?
Bluesky21 @ Swedish Chef. In China you can get cognac delivered to your home in under 20 minutes in some major cities
BE11:26am

Thing is, if your business does 90% gross margin historically and you figure that tempering longer term expectations can be done as a throwaway comment at a semi-formal investor meet, don't expect folks to retain much confidence that they have the full picture of how your business is operating.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

That's a risky game at 40x.

BE11:32am

Hence, they're down a bit. Here's Citi.

Bluesky21 Wetherspoons has +3.5% LfL in 13 weeks to 29 April
Grouchmonkey @SwedishChef Amazon Prime? I use them for all weird cocktail-type booze purchases these days. Just easier than schlepping round shops explaining to people what you are looking for
Bluesky21 Which has 1 less bank holiday than last year and also included all that snow in March
BE11:33am

FY18 PBT is £243m (Reuters consensus & Citi £245m) and EPS is 62.7p (cons 63.4p, Citi 63.1p). As expected the dividend has been maintained at 33.2p. Following last year’s weak LFL of -1.7% (vs Coffer Peach average -0.1%) this year has started stronger with LFL +2.2% in the last 8 weeks vs May Coffer Peach LFL +1.4%. This performance is against a flat comp and the combination of the recent VSQ investments, an easier comp through the rest of the year and the World Cup means the company sees positive LFL growth through FY19E (Citi +2%). When combined with a plan to mitigate £30m-£35m of the expected £45m-£50m cost headwinds and £3m-£4m of interest cost savings this should underpin current consensus forecasts (£245m)

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Cash flow and leverage metrics remain robust. Net debt fell modestly to £2,032m (Citi £2,051m) on the back of solid cash generation and despite onerous contract costs and £104m one off costs in part related to the recent refinancing activity. Group net debt/EBITDA is now at 4.2x in the middle of the targeted 4.0-4.5x range. Fixed charge cover is 2.2x. The GK Securitization and Spirit Debenture have FCF DSCR covenant headroom of 28% and 33% respectively. Following the repayment of the A1, A3, A6 and A7 Spirit notes there remains ongoing opportunity to refinance the remaining notes to lower interest and amortization costs.

BE11:34am

Implications — We make minor changes to estimates leaving our FY19E PBT essentially unchanged at £247m (EPS of 63.7p). The shares have rallied strongly following the reassuring trading update in April and the recent very favourable UK weather. The recent LFL growth, robust cost saving program and sustainable 5% dividend yield leave the shares well underpinned at current levels. We leave our DCF derived 730p target price unchanged and retain our Buy recommendation. We remain cognizant of continued macro uncertainties around the UK consumer and retain Sell recommendations on EIGE, MAB and MARS where we see significant ongoing risks around financial leverage.

BE11:34am

Readthrough? Yeah, there isn't any.

BE11:50am

The annual global carbon dioxide (CO2) market represents over 20 million metric tons of CO2 consumption in the merchant markets (2016 figures). Captive markets, such as the onsite manufacture of urea, methanol, sodium bicarbonate, and enhanced oil recovery (EOR) projects account for a significant additional tonnage, beyond the merchant market usage.

In the developed world, such as North America, Europe, and Japan, the major markets are dominated by the food industry in all three phases of the commodity’s form; that being gaseous, liquid, and solid (as snow or pressed dry ice products). According to Gasworld 70-80% of the total CO2 merchant market relates to the Food and Beverage industry with roughly 2/3 of this due to beverage carbonation and the rest a variety of applications including food freezing, abbatoir use and photosynthesis enrichment of greenhouse crops. Drinks carbonation includes fizzy sodas, sports drinks and water, champagnes and other sparkling wines and beer. Many of the larger breweries are CO2 generators in their beer fermentation but smaller ones are not.North America accounts for roughly half of captive industry demand.

The principal suppliers of non-captive carbon dioxide to the food industry are the industrial gas suppliers Air Liquide, Linde, Praxair and Air Products. Air Liquide have told us that curtailments at two ammonia plants in particular resulted in a tight European CO2 market, but suggest this is expected to be temporary with normal supplies returning in July. Along with their peers the majority of CO2 they sell is byproduct from ammonia plants though they also have a steam methane reformer (hydrogen plant) in Normandy with a carbon capture . AL have ponted out that its global CO2 sales are around €500m and total industry sales around €2bn making it 1/4 of the size of the non captive hydrogen market. It is a relatively small market representing 5% of their sales and dwarfed by oxygen/nitrogen and hydrogen sales. Whilst the ammonia plant shortages have impacted sales volume price increases have compensated thus far.

urgeview @ Tom Dagleish....he learnt from the master lol
BE11:51am

As is Trevor Stirling of Bernstein.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Net-net, there has been a material shortage of CO2 in NW Europe, with the UK hardest hit. Heineken UK has sent out emails to pubs stocking its beers alerting them to low stock levels of two keg beers, Amstel lager and John Smith's bitter; we understand the beer has been produced but can't be carbonated. However, as yet, we have not heard of supply problems on its highest volume keg beer, Foster's, and so far as we are aware Off-trade volumes (i.e. cans and bottles) have not been affected. AB InBev is less exposed to potential supply disruptions, as it has CO2 recovery systems at both of its breweries in the UK.

A. M. (CO2 EOR, at least in the US, is mostly-reliant on naturally-occurring CO2 sources)
Tom Dalgleish @Urge, I was no master in those days. Dave drove an Alfa Romeo, played rugby and studied Mining Engineering
BE11:52am

Don't panic, he says. Don't panic yet.

BE11:52am

Heineken is the most exposed to the possible dangers, with approximately 6.2% of profits coming from the UK (Carlsberg at 1.1% and ABI at 1%). Heineken also has the highest proportion of profits coming from NW Europe (UK, France, Belgium and the Netherlands) of 17%, with Carlsberg very close at 15%. If the crisis spreads to the Nordics, this would add a further 20% of EBIT at risk for Carlsberg from its beer and soft drinks businesses in Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland.

We estimate only 0.1% of group revenues will be affected this year for the industrial gas companies (Air Liquide and Linde). Their diversified product portfolio and geographic spread helps. Beyond gas manufactures, feed producers will also see an impact. Pig and poultry processors rely on CO2 for slaughtering. DSM (0.2%/group sales) and Evonik (0.1%) could be realistically impacted (we exclude feed for pets, which hopefully don't end up in the supermarket shelves).

Tom Dalgleish Dave always had a stateless manner about him

RBC incoming.

BE12:06pm

FY18 saw delivery on Bus EBIT and a Net Debt and EPS beat. Total DPS is re-set down at 7.7p (cons 11.9p). We see an asymmetric (to upside) value outlook – as with a more bus-centric EBIT mix there is PER multiple expansion potential – back to 13.5x (ex Rail) from present FY19E 7.5x.

Tom Dalgleish or maybe Goldman was Fooled by Randomness
Grouchmonkey Thanks @BE, particularly for the Greene King and CO2 stuff - useful. I am off down the pub.
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

FY18 10% EPS beat (on tax), FY19E cons EPS likely to hold at 18p but Net Debt lower: FY18 delivered 22.2p clean EPS (cons 20.1p) and FY DPS at 7.7p (11.9p cons). Net Debt was £396m (RBCe £512m) even with most of the East Coast exit cash flow in FY18. We see FY19E consensus EPS unchanged but cons Net Debt now likely to be lower at £470-480m as cash flow improves.
UK regional Bus stable: UK bus forecast changes (Exhibit 8) are almost unchanged with FY19E EBIT at £129.6m (£126.2m). This is in line with listed peers’ recent stable/better updates and also data (Q1-Cal-18) for all UK metropolitan areas outside London (-0.1%). To us, at 82% FY21E EBIT this is an important foundation to value.
Balance sheet better vs. previous RBCe -worth 8p/share equity upside in EV on an adverse 4.2p/share DPS re-set.
Dividend rebased at 7.7p sees 5.7% yield – but more sustainable, flexible and balance sheet firepower: The reset was not due to debt – FY18 exited at ND/EBITDA of 1.2x which we see peaking at 1.7x in FY21E at half the covenant limit of 3.5x. We believe the 7.7p is now fully supported by Bus-only FCF (Exhibit 5) and critically gives: (1) Flexibility (to relift later, or look at share buy backs); and (2) Firepower – preserving capital for M&A bolt-on opportunities.
Shares priced for ‘super-awful’: Exhibit 10 shows the shares now trade 10p below the 145p where we think the stock should trade if priced for loss of all UK rail, N America in run down (4x EBITDA); and, loss of the three largest UK bus city operations (London, Manchester, Newcastle) and with UK Bus at a distressed 6x EV/EBITDA multiple.
Long term ‘all bus’? Lower DPS (done), higher multiple (to come): Stagecoach could be ‘ex rail’ (FY21E) seeing EPS shrink (-5% FY19E-FY23E CAGR) and DPS flat at 7.7p. But we think PER expands. Long-term ex rail PER for SGC LN is 13.5x so FY21E EPS of 13p, plus cumulative DPS paid delivers estimated TSR by then of 200p – worth 18% implied upside 155-160p share today (not our PT as this includes total rail exit and loss of bus profits to franchising without replacement).

Tom Dalgleish so perhaps all long odds should have been watered down
BE12:07pm

RBC says that ignoring the "145p super-bear scenario, just applying a normal 7.2x EV/EBITDA sees 180p probable and 235p with no Big city bus loss to insourcing/franchising"
